awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear dimensionality reduction and enhanced sampling in molecular simulation using auto-associative neural networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Andrew Ferguson of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program in the Chemistry Division to establish new theoretical approaches and computational tools to accelerate molecular simulations of protein folding. This project is cofunded by the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory Program in the Division of Materials Research. Proteins are molecular workhorses that perform the essential functions of life.  Proteins have evolved to adopt shapes that enable them to do these tasks. Determining the shape and motions of a protein can help reveal how it works and inform how to design new proteins to help treat disease, produce biofuels, or make new materials. Computer simulations of proteins are very useful in that they can identify the precise locations and motions of all the constituent atoms. For all but the smallest proteins, however, it is too computationally intensive to accurately predict their structure and motions even with powerful supercomputers. Ways to accelerate these simulations have been developed, but to work well they need good estimates of the structural rearrangements that the protein will make. This is a problem, since this is usually the question the simulations are trying to answer. In this work, Professor Ferguson is developing a new approach to accelerate protein folding simulations using a type of machine learning known as artificial neural networks so-called because they are based on the structure of neurons in the brain.  Neural networks allow computers to both determine these important structural pathways and use them to make simulations run faster. This new approach is being used to help understand large proteins involved in cancer and HIV infection.  It is also being incorporated into popular simulation software available for free public download. Professor Ferguson is providing research opportunities for undergraduates to work with him on this project and he is developing hands-on workshops in computational materials science as part of the Girls Learning About Materials (GLAM) summer camp at the University of Illinois. 

The aim of this work is to establish a nonlinear machine learning approach to discover collective variables for protein folding and to use these variables to perform enhanced sampling in molecular dynamics simulations. The success of enhanced sampling techniques in accelerating conformational sampling is predicated on the availability of good collective variables (CVs) correlated with important molecular motions. Existing nonlinear dimensionality reduction techniques (e.g., diffusion maps, Isomap, land ocally linear embedding) can ably discover good CVs, but do not furnish the explicit coordinate mapping so that biased sampling must be conducted inefficiently and indirectly in proxy variables. This work establishes a new enhanced sampling approach based on auto-associative artificial neural networks ("autoencoders") to discover CVs that are explicit differentiable functions of the atomic coordinates and to permit calculation of analytical biasing forces. This approach is termed MESA (Molecular Enhanced Sampling with Autoencoders). MESA is validated on the short peptides alanine dipeptide and tryptophan-cage, and deployed to discover metastable states and structural transitions in a kinase overexpressed in many cancers and an envelope protein presented on the surface of HIV. MESA is made broadly available to the molecular simulation community by collaborating with the developers of OpenMM and PLUMED to contribute the approach to future releases of these software packages. Positive research experiences have great benefits for undergraduate success and retention and this work supports 10-week summer research opportunities during each year of the award. Professor Ferguson is also developing new and exciting content for the highly successful Girls Learning About Materials (GLAM) summer camp at the University of Illinois to illustrate and promote computational materials science among female high school students and elevate female enrollment in STEM degree programs.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported an integrated research and education program to develop new machine learning approaches to understand and control the microscopic behavior of biomolecules such as proteins and DNA. Computer simulations are a powerful tool to probe the molecular structure and dynamics of these molecules, but it is challenging to model the full range of possible conformations and transitions on even the most powerful supercomputers due to the large number of atomic coordinates that must be simulated. Molecular systems are "complex systems" in the sense that there is an emergent simplicity in which the important conformational states and dynamical transitions are governed by a small number of so-called collective variables formed by combinations of the atomic coordinates. Identifying these important collective variables is the key to unlocking new fundamental understanding of molecular systems, controlling their behavior, and conducting more efficient molecular simulations capable of sampling the relevant structures and dynamics. Specific applications include understanding and controlling biological enzymes that catalyze chemical reactions or engineering DNA strands that can be used in molecular sensing and nanotechnology. For all but the simplest systems, it is essentially impossible to guess what these collective variables are and so we must typically learn them in a data-driven fashion from molecular simulation trajectories.

This work established three new computational approaches to perform data-driven collective variable discovery and accelerated sampling in molecular simulations of protein folding and DNA association/dissociation. All three approaches were enabled by integrating modern deep learning techniques based on neural networks with mathematical models from the field of statistical thermodynamics that describe the thermodynamic and dynamical behavior of molecular systems. Through this synthesis, we devised powerful new approaches to perform data-driven collective variable discovery from molecular dynamics simulations and used these collective variables to gain deep understanding of the microscopic mechanisms and pathways governing the folding and unfolding of small proteins, and the assembly and disassembly of short DNA strands. Computationally, we developed a suite of new methods for the molecular simulation community that researchers can apply to help understand and accelerate the simulations of a range of biomolecular systems. Physically, we discovered within computer simulations previously unknown metastable states of small fast-folding proteins that could not be resolved by existing techniques, and sequence-dependent hybridization pathways for DNA oligomers that were subsequently supported by experimental spectroscopy measurements.

The award supported eight scientific publications; more than three dozen scientific presentations at academic conferences and departmental seminars; collaborations with one experimental research group; the publication of an invited review article; and the development of a number of new algorithms for collective variable discovery and enhanced sampling that were made freely available to the community through open-source codes hosted on GitHub and integrated into the PLUMED and SSAGES enhanced sampling libraries. One of the scientific publications emerging from this work was selected for the 2020 HOT Article Collection in the flagship journal of the Royal Society of Chemistry, another was selected as an American Chemical Society Editor?s Pick, and a third was one of the top 10% most downloaded papers in the journal in the 12 months following its publication.

In addition to the scientific activities, this award also supported integrated educational, outreach, and workforce development activities. Two post-docs, two graduate students, and four undergraduate students contributed to the work conducted under this award and received scientific training in molecular simulation and machine learning and mentoring in scientific communication and professional and personal development. Of the trainees who graduated over the course of this award, one postdoctoral researcher secured a senior research position at the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS) division of NIH, one graduate student secured employment as a data scientist with Teza Technologies, and one undergraduate student entered the Materials Science and Engineering PhD program at MIT. The award also supported the development and delivery of a workshop on computer simulation of materials modeling crack propagation in cheese that was delivered to the Girls Learning About Materials (GLAM) summer camp and hosted on the NSF-supported nanoHUB.org for free download and use by other instructors, students, and the general public.
